Problem:
Consider a function defined in the complex plane \( z(t) \) which evolves according to the differential equation \( \dot{z} = i \omega z \), where \( \omega \) is a constant real number representing angular frequency. We explore the effect of a transformation \( f(z) = e^{kt}z \) applied to this system, where \( k \) is a complex constant.

If \( f(z) \) is applied to a complex number \( z_0 \) at t = 0, and then \( z(t) \) is allowed to evolve according to \( \dot{z} = i \omega z \) up until t = T, will \( z(T) \) be the same as if \( z_0 \) was directly evolved under \( \dot{z} = i \omega z \) without the transformation \( f(z) \)?
Explanation: By applying \( f(z) \), \( z_0 \) is initially scaled by \( e^{k0} = 1 \), but as \( t \) progresses, the factor \( e^{kt} \) modifies the trajectory by adding an exponential growth or decay dependent on the real part of \( k \). This results in a different value for \( z(T) \) than without the transformation.
